page.title: 10ANGMERING PARK
page.content: Angmering park is 1,100 acres leased from the Norfolk Estate, planted in 1950 as a forest to replace hazel coppice with oak. The forest today is a mixed forest, norway spruce, scots pine, douglas fir, corsican pine and oak, beech and chestnut. Production of timber is accomplished by using a system of block planting. Different blocks are planted at different dates to ensure continuous rotation and production. The block is cleared mechanically, then saplings are interplanted at 2m intervals (2,000 trees/acre) with conifers interplanted between deciduous trees. Weeding is done mechanically for 5 years. At 5 and 10 year intervals, thinnings become pulp and fencing. At 50 years conifers are removed fully for construction, giving hardwoods space to mature for furniture at 140 years.
